head.title: Congo Leader Hedges on Vow to Allow Access for U.N. Force

hedline.hl1: Congo Leader Hedges on Vow to Allow Access for U.N. Force

abstract.p: Congo Pres Laurent Kabila appears to hedge on pledge to allow access for UN peacekeeping force of about 5,500 (M)

block.p: A week of conflicting signals from President Laurent Kabila of Congo has left the Security Council no closer to knowing when, if ever, a peacekeeping mission can be sent to the country. The council this week decided that United Nations officials who have been in Congo preparing for the peacekeepers could stay until Oct. 15, giving Secretary General Kofi Annan and the council time to reconsider the operation.

After announcing on Thursday that the peacekeepers and support forces, totaling about 5,500 people under current plans, could have free access in Congo, Mr. Kabila's government appeared today to be backtracking, officials said here.

The council this week decided that United Nations officials who have been in Congo preparing for the peacekeepers could stay until Oct. 15, giving Secretary General Kofi Annan and the council time to reconsider the operation.

After announcing on Thursday that the peacekeepers and support forces, totaling about 5,500 people under current plans, could have free access in Congo, Mr. Kabila's government appeared today to be backtracking, officials said here.

In nearly a year of trying to prepare for a peacekeeping operation in a country with inadequate roads, electrical supplies or other basic services in many areas, the United Nations advance team has met repeated obstacles. Because Congo officials always try to control flights and other activities, the Security Council has demanded freedom of movement without the need for permits or advance notice as the United Nations establishes centers of operation.

In Congo, United Nations officials have faced not only operational hurdles but also orchestrated hostility against international workers, including attacks on United Nations' offices in Kinshasa, the capital. Officials said they fear more violence if the government does not stop encouraging or condoning the anti-United Nations feelings.

This week, Mr. Annan sent a Nigerian general and former military ruler, Abdulsalami Abubakar, to Congo to tell Mr. Kabila that he must cooperate with the United Nations if the peacekeeping mission is to go ahead. General Abubakar will report to Mr. Annan next week.

Complicating the picture for a peacekeeping mission, Mr. Kabila said this week that he was freezing a peace accord signed last year in Lusaka, Zambia. That agreement set up a series of steps toward reconciliation in Congo, which has been caught in a prolonged war of shifting alliances for more than five years. Five other countries have been drawn into the conflict, unsettling much of south-central Africa.

An African diplomat said this week that some regional leaders have concluded that if Mr. Kabila cannot defeat several rebel groups operating in the country, most of them with outside support, he will retreat to his home territory around Lumbumbashi and leave the rest of Congo to the competing groups.

In one positive move, Mr. Kabila, who refuses to meet with political opponents, has established a human rights panel in Congo and allowed a United Nations monitor to visit the country in recent weeks. The monitor, Roberto Garreton, a lawyer from Chile, had been barred from Congo for several years.

Although Mr. Garreton's final report has not been published, he said this week when he left Congo that there was little good news in either government-controlled or rebel-controlled areas or in border regions where Rwanda and Uganda still have troops.
